newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spain could make reprisals after Cuban incidents.
newsitem.headline: Spain could make reprisals after Cuban incidents.

text.p: Spain held out the possibility on Tuesday of countermeasures against Cuba, including the expulsion of its ambassador in Madrid, if actions against Spanish interests continued, a senior Spanish official told Reuters.
"We don't rule out any type of measures, positive or negative," the official, who did not want to be named, said.
The comment followed reports, which the Foreign Ministry confirmed on Tuesday, of incidents at the Spanish consul's house in Havana.

Vandals punctured the tyres of consul Eduardo Cerro's car and stole a television antenna from his house on Monday night, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said. No further details were immediately available.
Diplomatic sources in Havana said burglars had stolen a television antenna from outside the consul's home last week while he was away on a trip.
The incidents followed Cuba's withdrawal last week of its earlier approval for a new Spanish ambassador to Havana.

Relations between Spain and Cuba have deteriorated to their lowest point in years after Havana accused Madrid of meddling in its affairs by urging the European Union to adopt a tougher policy towards Cuba in a push for democratic reforms in the communist state.

Havana cancelled a planned Spanish book exhibit and conference in Cuba last week, according to the official, who said the Spanish government was not ruling out countermeasures including the ambassador's explusion.
"We can name a new ambassador (to Cuba) or not. We can have this woman here or not," said the official, referring to Cuba's ambassador to Spain, Rosario Navas.

Foreign Ministry officials said on Monday Spain might take several months to name a replacement ambassador to Cuba, and would only do so after Havana indicated that it would approve the new candidate.
The incident at the consul's residence came days after Spain asked Cuba to protect its embassy for fear of attacks.
Cuban authorities placed a security cordon around the embassy, posting hundreds of police and plain-clothes guards outside to head off any disturbances.
The new Spanish government of Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar has adopted a much tougher line in pressing for democratic reform in Cuba than its Socialist predecessor.
